===Cause and prevalence===
===Cause and prevalence===
Virtually no research has been conducted regarding the prevalence of necrophilic attraction among humans. Klaf and Brown<ref name="klaf">Klaf, Franklin S., and Brown, William (1958). "Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report," ''the Psychoanalytic Quarterly'', 29(143), 645-652. "Inhibited forms of necrophilia and necrophilic fantasies may occur more commonly then is generally realized."</ref> (1958) commented that, although rarely described, necrophilic fantasies may occur more often than is generally supposed.
Virtually no research has been conducted regarding the prevalence of necrophilic attraction among humans. Klaf and Brown<ref name="klaf">Klaf, Franklin S., and Brown, William (1958). "Necrophilia: Brief Review and Case Report," ''the Psychoanalytic Quarterly'', 29(143), 645-652. "Inhibited forms of necrophilia and necrophilic fantasies may occur more commonly then is generally realized."</ref> (1958) commented that, although rarely described, necrophilic fantasies may occur more often than is generally supposed.
â

[http://www.burknet.com/robsfantasy/section11a.html "Sexual attraction to corpses: a psychiatric review of necrophilia,"] ''Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law'', 17, 153-163.</ref> (1989) theorized that either of the following situations could be antecedents to necrophilia (pp. 161):
+
Rosman and Resnick<ref name="rosman">Rosman, Jonathan P., and Resnick, Phillip J. (1989). [http://www.burknet.com/robsfantasy/section11a.html "Sexual attraction to corpses: a psychiatric review of necrophilia,"] ''Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law'', 17, 153-163.</ref> (1989) theorized that either of the following situations could be antecedents to necrophilia (pp. 161):
#The necrophile develops poor self-esteem, perhaps due in part to a significant loss;
#The necrophile develops poor self-esteem, perhaps due in part to a significant loss;
#:(a) He (usually male) is very fearful of rejection by women and he desires a sexual object who is incapable of rejecting him; and/or
#:(a) He (usually male) is very fearful of rejection by women and he desires a sexual object who is incapable of rejecting him; and/or
Line 26: Line 25:
For psychologist/philosopher [[Erich Fromm]], necrophilia is a character orientation which is not necessarily sexual. It is expressed in an attraction to that which is dead or totally controlled. At the extreme, it results in destructiveness and a hatred of life.
For psychologist/philosopher [[Erich Fromm]], necrophilia is a character orientation which is not necessarily sexual. It is expressed in an attraction to that which is dead or totally controlled. At the extreme, it results in destructiveness and a hatred of life.
â
For Fromm, necrophilia is the opposite of [[Biophilia Hypothesis|biophilia]]. Unlike [[Freud]]'s death instinct, it is not biologically determined but results from upbringing. Fromm believed that the lack of love in the western society and the attraction to mechanistic control leads to necrophilia. Expressions of necrophilia are modern weapon systems, idolotry of technology, and the treatment of people as things in bureaucracy.
+
For Fromm, necrophilia is the opposite of [[Biophilia Hypothesis|biophilia]]. Unlike [[Freud]]'s death instinct, it is not biologically determined but results from upbringing. Fromm believed that the lack of love in the western society and the attraction to mechanistic control leads to necrophilia. Expressions of necrophilia are modern weapon systems, idolotry of technology, and the treatment of people as things in bureaucracy.
For further information, see Fromm's, ''The Heart of Man'' (Harper and Row, 1964) and ''The Anatomy of Human Destructiveness'', (Holt, Rinehart and Winston, 1970)
For further information, see Fromm's, ''The Heart of Man'' (Harper and Row, 1964) and ''The Anatomy of Human Destructiveness'', (Holt, Rinehart and Winston, 1970)
Line 38: Line 37:
''Also see [[Necrophilia in popular culture]]''
''Also see [[Necrophilia in popular culture]]''
â
In [[Toni Morrison]]'s [[novel]] ''[[Song of Solomon (novel)|Song of Solomon]]'', [[Song of Solomon (novel)|Macon Dead]] is explaining to his son [[Song of Solomon (novel)|Milkman]] that he is disturbed by the relationship that his wife/Milkman's mother [[Song of Solomon (novel)|Ruth Dead]] had with her father [[Song of Solomon (novel)|Dr. Foster]]. Shortly after Dr. Foster's death, Macon caught Ruth lying naked in bed with her father Dr. Foster's corpse, while sucking on his fingers. It is not known whether Ruth actually had sex with the dead Dr. Foster; and Macon is believed not to have caught her in the act. Yet, Macon seems to believe that intercourse occurred between Ruth and the corpse.
+
In [[Toni Morrison]]'s [[novel]] ''[[Song of Solomon (novel)|Song of Solomon]]'', [[Song of Solomon (novel)|Macon Dead]] is explaining to his son [[Song of Solomon (novel)|Milkman]] that he is disturbed by the relationship that his wife/Milkman's mother [[Song of Solomon (novel)|Ruth Dead]] had with her father [[Song of Solomon (novel)|Dr. Foster]]. Shortly after Dr. Foster's death, Macon caught Ruth lying naked in bed with her father Dr. Foster's corpse, while sucking on his fingers. It is not known whether Ruth actually had sex with the dead Dr. Foster; and Macon is believed not to have caught her in the act. Yet, Macon seems to believe that intercourse occurred between Ruth and the corpse.
â
In Algernon Charles Swinburne's poem, "The Leper," the speaker is scribe who had long desired a woman in the royal house where he is employed. When she contracts leprosy, she is deserted by all others. The scribe then takes care of her, and has an arguably necrophilic relationship with her.
+
In Algernon Charles Swinburne's poem, "The Leper," the speaker is scribe who had long desired a woman in the royal house where he is employed. When she contracts leprosy, she is deserted by all others. The scribe then takes care of her, and has an arguably necrophilic relationship with her.
Published in 1930, William Faulkner's "A Rose for Emily" tells the story of a lonely house ridden woman named Emily Grierson who deals with the strange circumstances of the man she loves, and her secret world of necrophilia.
Published in 1930, William Faulkner's "A Rose for Emily" tells the story of a lonely house ridden woman named Emily Grierson who deals with the strange circumstances of the man she loves, and her secret world of necrophilia.
Line 51: Line 50:
===Carl Tanzler===
===Carl Tanzler===
{{Main|Carl Tanzler}}
{{Main|Carl Tanzler}}
â
[[Carl Tanzler]] was a [[radiologist]] in [[Key West, Florida]] who developed a morbid obsession for Elena Milagro Hoyos (1910-1931). She was one of his patients, and she died from [[tuberculosis]] in 1931. With her parents' permission, Tanzler had an above ground [[mausoleum]] built for her, so she wouldn't decompose underground. He visited the tomb almost every night, but in 1933, his obsession apparently overcame him, as he took Hoyos' corpse home with him and kept it in his bed. He restored her body as best he could and kept a full wardrobe to dress her. As her body decomposed, he replaced the skin with wax and [[plaster of Paris]], and bought copious amounts of perfume, often several times a month. In 1940, one of Hoyos's surviving sisters became suspicious due to omnipresent rumors of Tanzler's necrophilia, and eventually confronted Tanzler at his home. She entered Tanzler's house and found Elena's corpse lying in his bed in an elegant dress, almost fully decomposed. Tanzler was later arrested and charged with "wantonly and maliciously destroying a grave and removing a body without authorization," but he was ultimately released, as the [[statute of limitations]] on the crime had expired.
+
[[Carl Tanzler]] was a [[radiologist]] in [[Key West, Florida]] who developed a morbid obsession for Elena Milagro Hoyos (1910-1931). She was one of his patients, and she died from [[tuberculosis]] in 1931. With her parents' permission, Tanzler had an above ground [[mausoleum]] built for her, so she wouldn't decompose underground. He visited the tomb almost every night, but in 1933, his obsession apparently overcame him, as he took Hoyos' corpse home with him and kept it in his bed. He restored her body as best he could and kept a full wardrobe to dress her. As her body decomposed, he replaced the skin with wax and [[plaster of Paris]], and bought copious amounts of perfume, often several times a month. In 1940, one of Hoyos's surviving sisters became suspicious due to omnipresent rumors of Tanzler's necrophilia, and eventually confronted Tanzler at his home. She entered Tanzler's house and found Elena's corpse lying in his bed in an elegant dress, almost fully decomposed. Tanzler was later arrested and charged with "wantonly and maliciously destroying a grave and removing a body without authorization," but he was ultimately released, as the [[statute of limitations]] on the crime had expired.
===Karen Greenlee===
===Karen Greenlee===
[[Karen Greenlee]] made national headlines in the early 80s when she drove off in a hearse and wasn't heard from for two days. She was interviewed in the book [[Apocalypse Culture]]. The excerpt [http://www.nokilli.com/sacto/karen-greenlee.htm "The Unrepentant Necrophile]: An Interview with Karen Greenlee" is available online.
[[Karen Greenlee]] made national headlines in the early 80s when she drove off in a hearse and wasn't heard from for two days. She was interviewed in the book [[Apocalypse Culture]]. The excerpt [http://www.nokilli.com/sacto/karen-greenlee.htm "The Unrepentant Necrophile]: An Interview with Karen Greenlee" is available online.
â  
===Graham Coutts===
===Graham Coutts===
{{Main|Graham Coutts}}
{{Main|Graham Coutts}}
Graham Coutts made national news headlines in 2004, after strangling a woman with tights. He had previously visited websites such as [[Necrobabes]].
Graham Coutts made national news headlines in 2004, after strangling a woman with tights. He had previously visited websites such as [[Necrobabes]].
â   â

Line 69: Line 65:
{{main|Davian behavior}}
{{main|Davian behavior}}
â
Necrophilia is not unknown in animals, with a number of confirmed observations.<ref name="Guardian 2: Electric Boogaloo">{{Cite web|url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/improbable/story/0,,1437560,00.html|title=Randy rock doves join party with the dead|accessdate=[[2007-06-17]]|publisher=The Guardian|year=2005}}</ref> [[Kees Moeliker]] allegedly made one of these observations while he was sitting in his office at the [[Natuurmuseum Rotterdam]], when he heard the distinctive thud of a bird hitting the glass facade of the building. Upon inspection, he discovered a drake mallard lying dead about two meters from the building. Next to the downed bird there was a second drake mallard standing close by. As he observed the odd couple, the living drake picked at the corpse of the dead one for a few minutes and then mounted the corpse and began [[Sexual Intercourse|copulating]] with it. The act of necrophilia lasted for about 75 minutes, in which time, according to Moeliker, the living drake took two short breaks before resuming with copulating behavior. Moeliker surmised that at the time of the collision with the window the two mallards were engaged in a common motif in [[duck]] behavior which is called [[Non-Human Animal Sexual Behavior|rape flight]]. "When one died the other one just went for it and didn't get any negative feedback -- well, didn't get any feedback," according to Moeliker.<ref name="Mallard Duck">{{cite journal | author=C.W. Moeliker| title=The first case of homosexual necrophilia in the Anas platyrhynchos (Aves:Anatidae)| journal=Deinsea - Annual of the Natural History Museum Rotterdam| year=2001| volume=8| page=243-247}}</ref><ref name="MallardDuck">{{Cite web|url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/story/0,9865,1432991,00.html|title=Necrophilia among ducks ruffles research feathers|accessdate=[[2007-06-17]]|publisher=Guardian Unlimited|year=2005|author=Donald MacLeod}}</ref> This is the first recorded case of necrophilia in the mallard duck- though not the only recorded case of [[homosexuality]] within the bird family.<ref name="NYTSqueak">{{cite news |first=Dinitia |last=Smith |title=Love That Dare Not Squeak Its Name |publisher=New York Times |page=7 |date=[[2004-02-07]]}}</ref>
+
Necrophilia is not unknown in animals, with a number of confirmed observations.<ref name="Guardian 2: Electric Boogaloo">{{Cite web|url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/improbable/story/0,,1437560,00.html|title=Randy rock doves join party with the dead|accessdate = 2007-06-17|publisher=The Guardian|year=2005}}</ref> [[Kees Moeliker]] allegedly made one of these observations while he was sitting in his office at the [[Natuurmuseum Rotterdam]], when he heard the distinctive thud of a bird hitting the glass facade of the building. Upon inspection, he discovered a drake mallard lying dead about two meters from the building. Next to the downed bird there was a second drake mallard standing close by. As he observed the odd couple, the living drake picked at the corpse of the dead one for a few minutes and then mounted the corpse and began [[Sexual Intercourse|copulating]] with it. The act of necrophilia lasted for about 75 minutes, in which time, according to Moeliker, the living drake took two short breaks before resuming with copulating behavior. Moeliker surmised that at the time of the collision with the window the two mallards were engaged in a common motif in [[duck]] behavior which is called [[Non-Human Animal Sexual Behavior|rape flight]]. "When one died the other one just went for it and didn't get any negative feedback -- well, didn't get any feedback," according to Moeliker.<ref name="Mallard Duck">{{cite journal | author=C.W. Moeliker| title=The first case of homosexual necrophilia in the Anas platyrhynchos (Aves:Anatidae)| journal=Deinsea - Annual of the Natural History Museum Rotterdam| year=2001| volume=8| page=243-247}}</ref><ref name="MallardDuck">{{Cite web|url=http://education.guardian.co.uk/higher/research/story/0,9865,1432991,00.html|title=Necrophilia among ducks ruffles research feathers|accessdate = 2007-06-17|publisher=Guardian Unlimited|year=2005|author=Donald MacLeod}}</ref> This is the first recorded case of necrophilia in the mallard duck- though not the only recorded case of [[homosexuality]] within the bird family.<ref name="NYTSqueak">{{cite news |first=Dinitia |last=Smith |title=Love That Dare Not Squeak Its Name |publisher=New York Times |page=7 |date=[[2004-02-07]]}}</ref>
â
In the case of a [[praying mantis]], necrophilia could be said to be part of their methods of reproduction. The larger female will often decapitate or even eat her mate during copulation.<ref name="Feldman">{{Cite web|url=http://www.colostate.edu/Depts/Entomology/courses/en507/papers_1999/feldman.htm|title=The Praying Mantis|accessdate=[[2007-06-17]]|author=Dan Feldman}}</ref> However, since praying mantises have [[ganglia]] within the whole of their bodies,<ref>http://artemis.austincollege.edu/acad/bio/sgoldsmith/skg_ebe/preying_mantis.htm</ref><ref>http://www.biolbull.org/cgi/content/abstract/69/2/203</ref> with only one of these being in the head, the male could still be said to be sexually viable even after decapitation, and so necrophilia may not be an entirely appropriate term in this case.{{Who|date=July 2007}}
+
In the case of a [[praying mantis]], necrophilia could be said to be part of their methods of reproduction. The larger female will often decapitate or even eat her mate during copulation.<ref name="Feldman">{{Cite web|url=http://www.colostate.edu/Depts/Entomology/courses/en507/papers_1999/feldman.htm|title=The Praying Mantis|accessdate = 2007-06-17|author=Dan Feldman}}</ref> However, since praying mantises have [[ganglia]] within the whole of their bodies,<ref>http://artemis.austincollege.edu/acad/bio/sgoldsmith/skg_ebe/preying_mantis.htm</ref><ref>http://www.biolbull.org/cgi/content/abstract/69/2/203</ref> with only one of these being in the head, the male could still be said to be sexually viable even after decapitation, and so necrophilia may not be an entirely appropriate term in this case.{{Who|date=July 2007}}
